comment_text.mn38:2.1: The opening of this sutta is similar to MN 22.
comment_text.mn38:2.2: Sāti attributes three teachings to the Buddha. First, that there is a “transmigration” (saṁsāra) from one life to another. Second, that the primary locus of transmigration is “consciousness” (viññāṇa). And thirdly, that the consciousness that transmigrates remains “this very same” (tadevidaṁ), not another (anaññaṁ); in other words, it retains its self-same identity through the process of rebirth. The Buddha did in fact teach the first two of these ideas, but not the third, as he will explain below. | The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad says that as death approaches, the senses and vital energies withdraw into the heart (hṛdaya), from the top of which the self departs. That same consciousness proceeds to a new body (4.4.2: savijñāno bhavati, savijñānamevānvavakrāmati). This core Upaniṣadic chapter on rebirth reflects Sāti’s wording as well as his meaning. Sāti asserts emphatic identity using doubled demonstrative pronouns conjoined with (e)va (tadevidaṁ), and identical constructions are found throughout the Bṛhadāraṇyaka chapter: sa vā ayam (4.4.5), sa vā eṣa (4.4.22, 4.4.24, 4.4.25); see also tameva (4.4.17). For anaññaṁ we find the inverse anya for the “other” body (4.4.3, 4.4.4). For the Pali verbs sandhāvati saṁsarati we have instead avakrāmati (4.4.1, 4.4.2). But the connection with saṁsarati is made in the Brahmanical tradition itself, for it says below, “That self is indeed divinity, made of consciousness” (sa vā ayamātmā brahma vijñānamayo; 4.4.5, see too 4.4.22), which the commentator Śaṅkara explains as “the transmigrating self” (saṁsaratyātmā).
comment_text.mn38:3.10: If consciousness is dependent it is changeable and cannot be “that very same”. The Buddha spoke of consciousness as a process of phenomena evolving and flowing, ever changing like a stream.
comment_text.mn38:8.1: The Buddha’s use of duplicated pronouns with eva here echoes Sāti’s language, but to the opposite effect. Rather than emphasizing the self-sameness of transmigrating consciousness, the Buddha states with equal emphasis the dependence of consciousness on specific conditions, whatever they may be.
comment_text.mn38:8.8: A similar argument is made in the context of caste at MN 93:11.5.
comment_text.mn38:9.1: “This has come to be” (bhūtamidaṁ) refers to dependently originated consciousness (implied by the neuter pronoun idaṁ). See SN 12.31:7.1.
comment_text.mn38:11.1: This is the stream-enterer, who has seen dependent origination and given up doubt.
comment_text.mn38:14.1: An allusion to MN 22:13.1. The verbs here are used of children playing with sandcastles at SN 23.2:2.2.
comment_text.mn38:16.1: The word āhāra (“fuel”, “food”, “nutriment”) means literally “intake”, and is etymologically parallel to upādāna, “grasping”, “uptake”. Both terms have dual senses, on the one hand denoting fuel or sustenance, and on the other grasping and attachment. That is why here (as at MN 9:11.5), āhāra is created by craving, just like upādāna in the standard sequence (MN 38:17.8).
comment_text.mn38:17.1: Here begins the full presentation of the standard sequence of dependent origination in forward order. Formal definitions are found at SN 12.2. Here I briefly indicate the nature of the conditioned links. | Because we are ignorant of the four noble truths, we make morally potent choices by body, speech, and mind.
comment_text.mn38:17.2: These choices are creative forces or energies in the mind that sustain the ongoing stream of sense consciousness from one life to the next.
comment_text.mn38:17.3: Consciousness functions in relation to a cluster of phenomena both mental—feeling, perception, intention, contact, and application of mind—and physical—the four elements. These form an organism that grows and evolves.
comment_text.mn38:17.4: The sentient organism of the body requires senses to feed it stimuli.
comment_text.mn38:17.5: Through these the sentient organism encounters the world outside and learns to make sense of it.
comment_text.mn38:17.6: It distinguishes experiences that are pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral.
comment_text.mn38:17.7: It reacts by wanting to have more pleasure and to escape pain.
comment_text.mn38:17.8: Grasping at pleasures, view, observances, and theories of self, one makes sense of the world so as to optimize the capacity of oneself to experience pleasure.
comment_text.mn38:17.9: This grasping binds one to time, to a continuity of existence in the realms of the senses or those of refined consciousness.
comment_text.mn38:17.10: Shedding the body one takes up a new one in one of the realms of existence, perpetuating the cycle.
comment_text.mn38:17.11: Being born, it is inevitable that one will experience the pains of broken teeth, wrinkled skin, crooked back, and ultimately the failure of the body that we call death.
comment_text.mn38:18.1: The Buddha grills his students, reinforcing learning by making sure they understand each point.
comment_text.mn38:19.3: This is the abstract principle of dependent origination. It establishes that dependent origination is concerned, not with universal truisms such as “everything is connected” or “everything must have a cause”, but with establishing specific links between one thing and another. This is a form of necessary condition—without one thing, the other cannot be. But it is stronger than mere necessity, as each condition is a close and vital support for its descendant. This abstract principle is often called “specific conditionality” (idappaccayatā), but note that in the suttas idappaccayatā is a synonym of dependent origination as a whole.
comment_text.mn38:23.1: This passage unpacks certain aspects of ignorance. | Compare SN 12.20:5.1.
comment_text.mn38:23.4: Mahāsaṅgīti edition has the same verb paṭidhāv- here as above (“turn back to”). PTS and BJT have here ādhav- with paṭidhāv- as variant. At SN 12.20:5.3 all three editions have upadhāv-, with apadhāv- as variant in PTS. Whatever the correct reading might be, it is clear the intent is convey the opposite direction.
comment_text.mn38:24.2: Although the question is still in plural, the answer shifts to singular, perhaps by mistake because elsewhere this passage is always singular.
comment_text.mn38:24.5: “Respect for our teacher” is satthā no garu; compare samaṇo no garu at AN 3.65:4.1.
comment_text.mn38:24.8: Readings here are problematic and not cleared up by the commentary. I follow BJT and MS, which have a similar sense. However, both PTS and BJT plausibly have the pronoun no (“our”), which I add though absent from MS.
comment_text.mn38:24.12: In Buddhism, performance of rituals is not in itself forbidden; the main point is that they are not considered “essential” (sārato). Note that rituals were regarded as efficacious acts, and hence correspond to “choices” (saṅkhārā), a word that can also mean “rite”. | “Boisterous” (kotūhala) is literally “whence the hubbub?” This basic sense comes across clearly in the Arthaśāstra, which describes a spy’s spell for putting to sleep the men or dogs that guard a village, who are always listening out for sounds (14.3.21cd, 14.3.37ab). Vedic rituals, with their multiple reciters and arcane rites, took on a noisy and festive air.
comment_text.mn38:26.1: This section illustrates dependent origination by way of the birth and physical and psychological development of a person from conception to adulthood. From passages such as DN 15:21.2, we know that conception occurs at the nexus of “consciousness” and “name and form” in dependent origination. Since it starts with this life only, the first two factors, ignorance and choices, are omitted here, but are implicitly covered in the preceding passage. | For the “conception” or more literally “descent” of the embryo, the Buddha uses the same term avakkanti that, as we have noted (MN 38:2.2), was preferred by Yajñavālkya in the same context.
comment_text.mn38:26.2: According to MN 93:18.61 this was a doctrine of the brahmins, and it was evidently adopted in this sutta as a popular theory of conception. I discuss the role of the gandhabba in my notes there. | Utu (“the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle”) literally means “season”. As the earth needs rain, a womb is dry and infertile until it is moistened by blood, for the fortnight following which it is fertile and “in season”. Thus utu can be both menstruation, during which sex was taboo for the brahmins, as well as the fertile fortnight that follows, outside of which sex was also taboo (Snp 2.7:9.2). Atharvaveda 14.2.37a speaks of parents coming together “in season”. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.6 expresses the same idea by saying the woman should be approached for sex when she has removed her soiled garments (since she may not change clothes while menstruating, 6.4.13). Manu 3.46 defines the “season” as the sixteen days beginning with the appearance of the menstrual flow. The first four days are deemed inappropriate for sex on account of menstruation; and the eleventh and thirteenth day are also excluded, leaving ten days suitable for sex.
comment_text.mn38:27.1: “At great risk” is mahatā saṁsayena. | A term of pregnancy of “nine or ten months” is also found at Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.9.1. | For “heavy burden” (garubhāra) see Bi Pc 61:1.5.
comment_text.mn38:27.4: The Buddha’s claim that this idea is distinct to him seems to be borne out, as I cannot locate it in non-Buddhist texts.
comment_text.mn38:28.1: This shows that dependent origination does not happen all at once; it is a process of growth and maturation. A child, whose faculties are not developed, does not perpetuate the cycle because they have no formed moral intentions.
comment_text.mn38:28.2: A more extensive list of games is found at DN 1:1.14.2.
comment_text.mn38:29.3: In dependent origination, this parallels contact through the senses giving rise to feelings.
comment_text.mn38:30.1: In dependent origination, feeling gives rise to craving. | Parallel passages in the Saṁyutta (eg. SN 35.132:12.3) in parallels for this passage have adhimuccati (‘commits to, holds on to”) rather than sārajjati (“desires”).
comment_text.mn38:30.5: Now we rejoin the standard sequence of dependent origination.
comment_text.mn38:31.1: Just as the sutta illustrated the abstract arising of suffering with the concrete example of a child growing up, it now illustrates the unraveling of dependent origination with the Gradual Training (see MN 27:11.1).
comment_text.mn38:40.1: This resumes the teaching on attachment to the senses (from MN 38:30.1), having shown what is required to let go such attachment. Here, one experiences the feelings through the senses, but without any attachment.
comment_text.mn38:41.11: The mention of the “brief statement” at the end of a long discourse is puzzling. A similar exhortation to “memorize” a “brief” passage is found in only one other passage, where it is in reference to the short summary passage around which the sutta is based (MN 140:32.3). Compare the preceding sutta, MN 37, which revolves around a short passage for memorization that is fittingly described as “brief” throughout. That “brief” passage opens by saying “nothing is worth insisting on”, advice that is disregarded by Sāti who “insists” on his own view (MN 38:3.11). No “brief statement” is mentioned in the Chinese parallel (MA 201 at T i 769c28), which speaks instead of the shaking of the three-thousand-fold world system.

root_text.mn38:8.14: saṅkārañca paṭicca aggi jalati, saṅkāraggitveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn38:8.15: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yaṁ yadeva paccayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, tena teneva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn38:8.16: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, cakkhuviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn38:8.17: sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, sotaviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati,
root_text.mn38:8.18: ghānañca paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, ghānaviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati,
root_text.mn38:8.19: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, jivhāviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn38:8.20: Kāyañca paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, kāyaviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn38:8.21: Manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati viññāṇaṁ, manoviññāṇantveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn38:9.5: “Tadāhāranirodhā yaṁ bhūtaṁ, taṁ nirodhadhammanti, bhikkhave, passathā”ti?
root_text.mn38:10.5: “Tadāhāranirodhā yaṁ bhūtaṁ, taṁ nirodhadhammaṁ nossūti, bhikkhave, kaṅkhato uppajjati vicikicchā”ti?
root_text.mn38:11.1: “Bhūtamidanti, bhikkhave, yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato yā vicikicchā sā pahīyatī”ti?
root_text.mn38:11.3: “Tadāhārasambhavanti, bhikkhave, yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato yā vicikicchā sā pahīyatī”ti?
root_text.mn38:11.5: “Tadāhāranirodhā yaṁ bhūtaṁ, taṁ nirodhadhammanti, bhikkhave, yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato yā vicikicchā sā pahīyatī”ti?
root_text.mn38:12.5: “Tadāhāranirodhā yaṁ bhūtaṁ taṁ nirodhadhammanti, bhikkhave, itipi vo ettha nibbicikicchā”ti?
root_text.mn38:13.5: “Tadāhāranirodhā yaṁ bhūtaṁ taṁ nirodhadhammanti, bhikkhave, yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhan”ti?
root_text.mn38:14.1: “Imañce tumhe, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ allīyetha kelāyetha dhanāyetha mamāyetha, api nu me tumhe, bhikkhave, kullūpamaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājāneyyātha nittharaṇatthāya no gahaṇatthāyā”ti?
root_text.mn38:14.3: “Imañce tumhe, bhikkhave, diṭṭhiṁ evaṁ parisuddhaṁ evaṁ pariyodātaṁ na allīyetha na kelāyetha na dhanāyetha na mamāyetha, api nu me tumhe, bhikkhave, kullūpamaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājāneyyātha nittharaṇatthāya no gahaṇatthāyā”ti?
root_text.mn38:15.1: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārā bhūtānaṁ vā sattānaṁ ṭhitiyā, sambhavesīnaṁ vā anuggahāya.
root_text.mn38:15.3: Kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṁ catutthaṁ.
root_text.mn38:16.1: Ime ca, bhikkhave, cattāro āhārā kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn38:16.2: Ime cattāro āhārā taṇhānidānā taṇhāsamudayā taṇhājātikā taṇhāpabhavā.
root_text.mn38:16.3: Taṇhā cāyaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn38:16.5: Vedanā cāyaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn38:16.7: Phasso cāyaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo?
root_text.mn38:16.9: Saḷāyatanañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ?
root_text.mn38:16.11: Nāmarūpañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ?
root_text.mn38:16.13: Viññāṇañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ?
root_text.mn38:16.15: Saṅkhārā cime, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn38:18.1: Jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ;
root_text.mn38:18.2: jātipaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, jarāmaraṇaṁ, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.7: bhavapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, jāti, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.12: upādānapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, bhavo, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.16: “Taṇhāpaccayā upādānanti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, taṇhāpaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, upādānaṁ, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.21: vedanāpaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, taṇhā, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.26: phassapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, vedanā, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.31: saḷāyatanapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, phasso, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.36: nāmarūpapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, saḷāyatanaṁ, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.41: viññāṇapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, nāmarūpaṁ, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.46: saṅkhārapaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:18.51: avijjāpaccayā nu kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:19.2: Iti kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi evaṁ vadetha, ahampi evaṁ vadāmi—
root_text.mn38:19.3: imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn38:21.1: Jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇanirodhoti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ;
root_text.mn38:21.2: jātinirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, jarāmaraṇanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.7: bhavanirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, jātinirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.12: upādānanirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, bhavanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.17: taṇhānirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, upādānanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.22: vedanānirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, taṇhānirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.27: phassanirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, vedanānirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.32: saḷāyatananirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, phassanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotīti?
root_text.mn38:21.37: nāmarūpanirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, saḷāyatananirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.42: viññāṇanirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, nāmarūpanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.47: saṅkhāranirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇanirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:21.52: avijjānirodhā nu kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhāranirodho, no vā, kathaṁ vā ettha hotī”ti?
root_text.mn38:22.2: Iti kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi evaṁ vadetha, ahampi evaṁ vadāmi—
root_text.mn38:22.3: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhati, yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn38:23.1: Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā pubbantaṁ vā paṭidhāveyyātha:
root_text.mn38:23.2: ‘ahesumha nu kho mayaṁ atītamaddhānaṁ, nanu kho ahesumha atītamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ nu kho ahesumha atītamaddhānaṁ, kathaṁ nu kho ahesumha atītamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ hutvā kiṁ ahesumha nu kho mayaṁ atītamaddhānan’”ti?
root_text.mn38:23.4: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā aparantaṁ vā paṭidhāveyyātha—
root_text.mn38:23.5: bhavissāma nu kho mayaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, nanu kho bhavissāma anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ nu kho bhavissāma anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kathaṁ nu kho bhavissāma anāgatamaddhānaṁ, kiṁ hutvā kiṁ bhavissāma nu kho mayaṁ anāgatamaddhānan”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.1: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā etarahi vā paccuppannamaddhānaṁ ajjhattaṁ kathaṅkathī assatha—
root_text.mn38:24.2: ahaṁ nu khosmi, no nu khosmi, kiṁ nu khosmi, kathaṁ nu khosmi, ayaṁ nu kho satto kuto āgato, so kuhiṁ gāmī bhavissatī”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.4: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā evaṁ vadeyyātha—
root_text.mn38:24.5: satthā no garu, satthugāravena ca mayaṁ evaṁ vademā”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.7: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā evaṁ vadeyyātha—
root_text.mn38:24.8: samaṇo evamāha, samaṇā ca nāma mayaṁ evaṁ vademā”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.10: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā aññaṁ satthāraṁ uddiseyyāthā”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.12: “Api nu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ jānantā evaṁ passantā yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ vata kotūhalamaṅgalāni tāni sārato paccāgaccheyyāthā”ti?
root_text.mn38:24.14: “Nanu, bhikkhave, yadeva tumhākaṁ sāmaṁ ñātaṁ sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ sāmaṁ viditaṁ, tadeva tumhe vadethā”ti.
root_text.mn38:25.1: “Sādhu, bhikkhave, upanītā kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, iminā sandiṭṭhikena dhammena akālikena ehipassikena opaneyyikena paccattaṁ veditabbena viññūhi.
root_text.mn38:25.2: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi—
root_text.mn38:25.3: iti yantaṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttanti.
root_text.mn38:26.1: Tiṇṇaṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, sannipātā gabbhassāvakkanti hoti.
root_text.mn38:26.2: Idha mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā ca na utunī hoti, gandhabbo ca na paccupaṭṭhito hoti, neva tāva gabbhassāvakkanti hoti.
root_text.mn38:26.3: Idha mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā ca utunī hoti, gandhabbo ca na paccupaṭṭhito hoti, neva tāva gabbhassāvakkanti hoti.
root_text.mn38:26.4: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, mātāpitaro ca sannipatitā honti, mātā ca utunī hoti, gandhabbo ca paccupaṭṭhito hoti—evaṁ tiṇṇaṁ sannipātā gabbhassāvakkanti hoti.
root_text.mn38:27.1: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, mātā nava vā dasa vā māse gabbhaṁ kucchinā pariharati mahatā saṁsayena garubhāraṁ.
root_text.mn38:27.2: Tamenaṁ, bhikkhave, mātā navannaṁ vā dasannaṁ vā māsānaṁ accayena vijāyati mahatā saṁsayena garubhāraṁ.
root_text.mn38:27.3: Tamenaṁ jātaṁ samānaṁ sakena lohitena poseti.
root_text.mn38:27.4: Lohitañhetaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye yadidaṁ mātuthaññaṁ.
root_text.mn38:28.1: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, kumāro vuddhimanvāya indriyānaṁ paripākamanvāya
root_text.mn38:28.2: yāni tāni kumārakānaṁ kīḷāpanakāni tehi kīḷati, seyyathidaṁ—vaṅkakaṁ ghaṭikaṁ mokkhacikaṁ ciṅgulakaṁ pattāḷhakaṁ rathakaṁ dhanukaṁ.
root_text.mn38:29.1: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, kumāro vuddhimanvāya indriyānaṁ paripākamanvāya
root_text.mn38:29.3: cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṁhitehi rajanīyehi,
root_text.mn38:29.7: kāyaviññeyyehi phoṭṭhabbehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṁhitehi rajanīyehi.
root_text.mn38:30.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe sārajjati, appiyarūpe rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyasati ca viharati parittacetaso.
root_text.mn38:30.2: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti yatthassa te pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:30.3: So evaṁ anurodhavirodhaṁ samāpanno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn38:30.4: Tassa taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
root_text.mn38:30.5: Yā vedanāsu nandī tadupādānaṁ, tassupādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
root_text.mn38:30.11: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme sārajjati, appiyarūpe dhamme byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyasati ca viharati parittacetaso.
root_text.mn38:30.12: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti yatthassa te pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:30.13: So evaṁ anurodhavirodhaṁ samāpanno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn38:30.14: Tassa taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
root_text.mn38:30.15: Yā vedanāsu nandī tadupādānaṁ, tassupādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
root_text.mn38:31.1: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn38:31.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn38:31.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ;
root_text.mn38:32.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn38:32.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn38:32.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn38:32.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn38:32.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā, kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’”ti.
root_text.mn38:32.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā, kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn38:33.1: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn38:33.2: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn38:33.3: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti, ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
root_text.mn38:33.4: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
root_text.mn38:33.5: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti—ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī, samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn38:33.6: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti—yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn38:33.7: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā kālena, sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn38:34.1: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn38:34.2: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
root_text.mn38:34.3: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn38:34.4: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn38:35.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn38:35.2: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn38:35.7: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn38:35.8: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn38:35.9: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn38:36.1: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn38:37.1: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato,
root_text.mn38:37.2: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati—araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn38:38.1: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn38:38.2: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn38:38.3: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn38:38.4: thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī, sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn38:38.5: uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn38:38.6: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn38:39.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
root_text.mn38:39.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn38:39.3: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn38:40.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe na sārajjati, appiyarūpe rūpe na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyasati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso.
root_text.mn38:40.2: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti yatthassa te pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:40.3: So evaṁ anurodhavirodhavippahīno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti, sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn38:40.4: Tassa taṁ vedanaṁ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā vedanāsu nandī sā nirujjhati.
root_text.mn38:40.5: Tassa nandīnirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:41.5: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme na sārajjati, appiyarūpe dhamme na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyasati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso,
root_text.mn38:41.6: tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti yatthassa te pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:41.7: So evaṁ anurodhavirodhavippahīno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti, sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
root_text.mn38:41.8: Tassa taṁ vedanaṁ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā vedanāsu nandī sā nirujjhati.
root_text.mn38:41.9: Tassa nandīnirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn38:41.11: Imaṁ kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ dhāretha, sātiṁ pana bhikkhuṁ kevaṭṭaputtaṁ mahātaṇhājālataṇhāsaṅghāṭappaṭimukkan”ti.
root_text.mn38:41.13: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn38:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving
translation_text.mn38:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn38:2.1: Now at that time a mendicant called Sāti, the fisherman’s son, had the following harmful misconception:
translation_text.mn38:2.2: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
translation_text.mn38:3.4: They went up to Sāti and said to him,
translation_text.mn38:3.5: “Is it really true, Reverend Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception:
translation_text.mn38:3.6: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”
translation_text.mn38:3.7: “Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
translation_text.mn38:3.8: Then, wishing to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him,
translation_text.mn38:3.9: “Don’t say that, Sāti! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
translation_text.mn38:3.10: In many ways the Buddha has said that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”
translation_text.mn38:3.11: But even though the mendicants pressed him in this way, Sāti obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on it.
translation_text.mn38:4.1: When they weren’t able to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn38:5.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
translation_text.mn38:5.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Sāti that
translation_text.mn38:5.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Sāti and said to him,
translation_text.mn38:5.6: “Yes, reverend,” Sāti replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn38:5.7: “Is it really true, Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception:
translation_text.mn38:5.8: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”
translation_text.mn38:5.9: “Absolutely, sir. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
translation_text.mn38:5.11: “Sir, he is the one who speaks, the one who knows, who experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms.”
translation_text.mn38:5.12: “Futile man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach in that way?
translation_text.mn38:5.13: Haven’t I said in many ways that consciousness is dependently originated, since consciousness does not arise without a cause?
translation_text.mn38:5.14: But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and brim with much wickedness.
translation_text.mn38:5.15: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
translation_text.mn38:6.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
translation_text.mn38:6.3: Has this mendicant Sāti kindled even a spark of ardor in this teaching and training?”
translation_text.mn38:6.6: When this was said, Sāti sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
translation_text.mn38:6.8: “Futile man, you will be known by your own harmful misconception.
translation_text.mn38:6.9: I’ll question the mendicants about this.”
translation_text.mn38:7.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
translation_text.mn38:7.2: “Mendicants, do you understand my teachings as Sāti does, when he misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and brims with much wickedness?”
translation_text.mn38:7.4: For in many ways the Buddha has told us that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”
translation_text.mn38:7.6: It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
translation_text.mn38:7.7: For in many ways I have told you that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.
translation_text.mn38:7.8: But still this Sāti misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and brims with much wickedness.
translation_text.mn38:7.9: This will be for his lasting harm and suffering.
translation_text.mn38:8.1: Consciousness is reckoned according to the very same condition dependent upon which it arises.
translation_text.mn38:8.2: Consciousness that arises dependent on the eye and sights is reckoned as eye consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.3: Consciousness that arises dependent on the ear and sounds is reckoned as ear consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.4: Consciousness that arises dependent on the nose and smells is reckoned as nose consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.5: Consciousness that arises dependent on the tongue and tastes is reckoned as tongue consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.6: Consciousness that arises dependent on the body and touches is reckoned as body consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.7: Consciousness that arises dependent on the mind and ideas is reckoned as mind consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:8.8: It’s like fire, which is reckoned according to the very same condition dependent upon which it burns.
translation_text.mn38:8.9: A fire that burns dependent on logs is reckoned as a log fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.10: A fire that burns dependent on twigs is reckoned as a twig fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.11: A fire that burns dependent on grass is reckoned as a grass fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.12: A fire that burns dependent on cow-dung is reckoned as a cow-dung fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.13: A fire that burns dependent on husks is reckoned as a husk fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.14: A fire that burns dependent on rubbish is reckoned as a rubbish fire.
translation_text.mn38:8.15: In the same way, consciousness is reckoned according to the very same condition dependent upon which it arises. …
translation_text.mn38:9.1: Mendicants, do you see that this has come to be?”
translation_text.mn38:9.3: “Do you see that it originated with that as fuel?”
translation_text.mn38:9.5: “Do you see that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”
translation_text.mn38:10.1: “Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not this has come to be?”
translation_text.mn38:10.3: “Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not this has originated with that as fuel?”
translation_text.mn38:10.5: “Does doubt arise when you’re uncertain whether or not when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”
translation_text.mn38:11.1: “Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that this has come to be?”
translation_text.mn38:11.3: “Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that this has originated with that as fuel?”
translation_text.mn38:11.5: “Is doubt given up in someone who truly sees with right understanding that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”
translation_text.mn38:12.1: “Are you free of doubt as to whether this has come to be?”
translation_text.mn38:12.3: “Are you free of doubt as to whether this has originated with that as fuel?”
translation_text.mn38:12.5: “Are you free of doubt as to whether when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”
translation_text.mn38:13.1: “Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that this has come to be?”
translation_text.mn38:13.3: “Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that this has originated with that as fuel?”
translation_text.mn38:13.5: “Have you truly seen clearly with right understanding that when that fuel ceases, what has come to be is liable to cease?”
translation_text.mn38:14.1: “Pure and bright as this view is, mendicants, if you cling to it, dally with it, treasure it, and treat it as your own, would you be understanding my simile of the teaching as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on?”
translation_text.mn38:14.3: “Pure and bright as this view is, mendicants, if you don’t cling to it, dally with it, treasure it, and treat it as your own, would you be understanding my simile of the teaching as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on?”
translation_text.mn38:15.1: “Mendicants, these four fuels maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those about to be born.
translation_text.mn38:15.3: Edible food, whether solid or subtle; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.
translation_text.mn38:16.1: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four fuels?
translation_text.mn38:16.3: And what is the source of craving?
translation_text.mn38:16.5: And what is the source of feeling?
translation_text.mn38:16.7: And what is the source of contact?
translation_text.mn38:16.9: And what is the source of the six sense fields?
translation_text.mn38:16.11: And what is the source of name and form?
translation_text.mn38:16.13: And what is the source of consciousness?
translation_text.mn38:16.15: And what is the source of choices?
translation_text.mn38:17.1: So, ignorance is a requirement for choices.
translation_text.mn38:17.2: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:17.3: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.
translation_text.mn38:17.4: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.
translation_text.mn38:17.5: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.
translation_text.mn38:17.6: Contact is a requirement for feeling.
translation_text.mn38:17.7: Feeling is a requirement for craving.
translation_text.mn38:17.8: Craving is a requirement for grasping.
translation_text.mn38:17.9: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.
translation_text.mn38:17.10: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.
translation_text.mn38:17.11: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
translation_text.mn38:17.12: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
translation_text.mn38:18.1: ‘Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’ That’s what I said.
translation_text.mn38:18.2: Is that how you see this or not?”
translation_text.mn38:18.6: “‘Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.’ …
translation_text.mn38:18.50: ‘Ignorance is a requirement for choices.’ That’s what I said.
translation_text.mn38:18.51: Is that how you see this or not?”
translation_text.mn38:19.2: So both you and I say this.
translation_text.mn38:19.3: When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises. That is:
translation_text.mn38:19.4: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.
translation_text.mn38:19.5: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.
translation_text.mn38:19.6: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.
translation_text.mn38:19.7: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.
translation_text.mn38:19.8: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.
translation_text.mn38:19.9: Contact is a requirement for feeling.
translation_text.mn38:19.10: Feeling is a requirement for craving.
translation_text.mn38:19.11: Craving is a requirement for grasping.
translation_text.mn38:19.12: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.
translation_text.mn38:19.13: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.
translation_text.mn38:19.14: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
translation_text.mn38:19.15: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
translation_text.mn38:20.1: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
translation_text.mn38:20.3: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
translation_text.mn38:20.4: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.
translation_text.mn38:20.5: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.
translation_text.mn38:20.9: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
translation_text.mn38:20.10: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
translation_text.mn38:20.11: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
translation_text.mn38:20.12: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
translation_text.mn38:21.1: ‘When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.’ That’s what I said.
translation_text.mn38:21.2: Is that how you see this or not?”
translation_text.mn38:21.51: ‘When ignorance ceases, choices cease.’ That’s what I said.
translation_text.mn38:21.52: Is that how you see this or not?”
translation_text.mn38:22.2: So both you and I say this.
translation_text.mn38:22.3: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:
translation_text.mn38:22.6: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
translation_text.mn38:22.7: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.
translation_text.mn38:22.8: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.
translation_text.mn38:22.12: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
translation_text.mn38:22.13: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
translation_text.mn38:22.14: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
translation_text.mn38:22.15: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
translation_text.mn38:23.1: Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you turn back to the first beginning, thinking,
translation_text.mn38:23.2: ‘Did we exist in the past? Did we not exist in the past? What were we in the past? How were we in the past? After being what, what did we become in the past?’?”
translation_text.mn38:23.4: “Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you turn forward to the final end, thinking,
translation_text.mn38:23.5: ‘Will we exist in the future? Will we not exist in the future? What will we be in the future? How will we be in the future? After being what, what will we become in the future?’?”
translation_text.mn38:24.1: “Knowing and seeing in this way, mendicants, would you be undecided about the present, thinking,
translation_text.mn38:24.2: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This sentient being—where did it come from? And where will it go?’?”
translation_text.mn38:24.4: “Knowing and seeing in this way, would you say,
translation_text.mn38:24.5: ‘Our teacher is respected. We speak like this out of respect for our teacher’?”
translation_text.mn38:24.7: “Knowing and seeing in this way, would you say,
translation_text.mn38:24.8: ‘Our ascetic says this. We speak like this because it is what he says’?”
translation_text.mn38:24.10: “Knowing and seeing in this way, would you dedicate yourself to another teacher?”
translation_text.mn38:24.12: “Knowing and seeing in this way, would you believe that the observances and boisterous, superstitious rites of the various ascetics and brahmins are essential?”
translation_text.mn38:24.14: “Aren’t you speaking only of what you have known and seen and realized for yourselves?”
translation_text.mn38:25.1: “Good, mendicants! You have been guided by me with this teaching that’s apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
translation_text.mn38:25.2: For when I said that this teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves,
translation_text.mn38:25.3: this is what I was referring to.
translation_text.mn38:26.1: Mendicants, when three things come together an embryo is conceived.
translation_text.mn38:26.2: In a case where the mother and father come together, but the mother is not in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, and the virile spirit is not ready, the embryo is not conceived.
translation_text.mn38:26.3: In a case where the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, but the virile spirit is not ready, the embryo is not conceived.
translation_text.mn38:26.4: But when these three things come together—the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, and the virile spirit is ready—an embryo is conceived.
translation_text.mn38:27.1: The mother nurtures the embryo in her womb for nine or ten months at great risk to her heavy burden.
translation_text.mn38:27.2: When nine or ten months have passed, the mother gives birth at great risk to her heavy burden.
translation_text.mn38:27.3: When the infant is born she nourishes it with her own blood.
translation_text.mn38:27.4: For mother’s milk is regarded as blood in the training of the Noble One.
translation_text.mn38:28.1: That boy grows up and his faculties mature.
translation_text.mn38:28.2: He accordingly plays childish games such as toy plows, tipcat, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, and toy bows.
translation_text.mn38:29.1: That boy grows up and his faculties mature further.
translation_text.mn38:29.2: He accordingly amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn38:29.3: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn38:29.7: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn38:30.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they desire it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart stunted.
translation_text.mn38:30.2: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn38:30.3: Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it.
translation_text.mn38:30.5: Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a requirement for continued existence. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
translation_text.mn38:30.6: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
translation_text.mn38:30.7: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn38:30.8: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn38:30.9: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn38:30.10: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn38:30.11: When they know an idea with their mind, if it’s pleasant they desire it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart stunted.
translation_text.mn38:30.12: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn38:30.13: Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it.
translation_text.mn38:30.15: Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a requirement for continued existence. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
translation_text.mn38:30.16: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
translation_text.mn38:31.1: But consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn38:31.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn38:31.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased.
translation_text.mn38:31.4: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
translation_text.mn38:32.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn38:32.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
translation_text.mn38:32.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn38:32.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn38:32.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn38:32.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn38:33.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn38:33.2: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.mn38:33.3: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.mn38:33.4: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.mn38:33.5: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn38:33.6: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn38:33.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn38:33.8: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.mn38:33.9: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
translation_text.mn38:33.10: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
translation_text.mn38:33.11: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.mn38:33.12: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.mn38:33.13: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.mn38:33.22: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.mn38:33.26: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.mn38:34.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn38:34.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.mn38:34.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn38:34.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.mn38:35.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn38:35.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn38:35.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn38:35.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn38:35.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn38:35.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn38:35.7: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn38:35.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn38:35.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.mn38:36.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn38:37.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
translation_text.mn38:37.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn38:38.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn38:38.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn38:38.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.mn38:38.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn38:38.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn38:38.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn38:39.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn38:39.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn38:39.3: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn38:40.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they don’t desire it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
translation_text.mn38:40.2: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn38:40.3: Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it.
translation_text.mn38:40.4: As a result, relishing of feelings ceases.
translation_text.mn38:40.5: When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
translation_text.mn38:40.6: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
translation_text.mn38:41.1: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn38:41.2: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn38:41.3: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn38:41.4: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn38:41.5: When they know an idea with their mind, if it’s pleasant they don’t desire it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
translation_text.mn38:41.6: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
translation_text.mn38:41.7: Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it.
translation_text.mn38:41.8: As a result, relishing of feelings ceases.
translation_text.mn38:41.9: When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
translation_text.mn38:41.10: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
translation_text.mn38:41.11: Mendicants, you should memorize this brief statement on freedom through the ending of craving. But the mendicant Sāti, the fisherman’s son, is caught in a vast net of craving, a tangle of craving.”
translation_text.mn38:41.12: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn38:41.13: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
